```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

library(readxl)
library(dplyr)
```

## R Markdown

Great resource for dataset: <https://www.eia.gov/electricity/wholesale/>

```{r Dataset}
electricity_dataset <- read_excel("electricity-2024.xlsx")
electricity_dataset

head(electricity_dataset)
```

## 2014-2023 Dataset

```{r 2014-2015}

data_2014 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2014final.xls")
data_2014

data_2015 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2015final.xls")
data_2015

data_2016 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2016final.xls")
data_2016

data_2017 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2017final.xlsx")
data_2017

data_2018 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2018final.xlsx")
data_2018

data_2019 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2019final.xlsx")
data_2019

data_2020 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2020final.xlsx")
data_2020

data_2021 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2021final.xlsx")
data_2021

data_2022 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2022final.xlsx")
data_2022 <- select(data_2022, -'Trade date') # REMOVE COLUMN because it's bad
data_2022$'Trade date' <- data_2022$`Delivery start date` - 86400  # 86400 seconds in a day
data_2022

data_2023 <- read_excel ("./Data/ice_electric-2023final.xlsx")
data_2023
```

## Head 2014-2023

```{r head}

head(data_2014) # BEGIN "ERCOT North 345KV Peak"...
head(data_2015)
head(data_2016)
head(data_2017)
head(data_2018)
head(data_2019) # END "ERCOT North 345KV Peak"
head(data_2020) # BEGIN "Indiana Hub RT Peak"...
head(data_2021)
head(data_2022)
head(data_2023) # END "Indiana Hub RT Peak"
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
